      • force

        public void force​(IOLimiter ioLimiter,
                  PageCursorTracer cursorTracer)
           throws IOException
        The force()-method is called during log rotation. At this time we do not want to wait for locks held by FlippableIndexProxy.LockingIndexUpdater. Waiting on such locks would cause a serious risk of deadlocks, since very likely the reader we would be waiting on would be waiting on the log rotation lock held by the thread calling this method. The reason we would wait for a read lock while trying to acquire a read lock is if there is a third thread waiting on the write lock, probably an index populator wanting to flip the index into active state.

        We avoid this deadlock situation by "barging" on the read lock, i.e. acquire it in an unfair way, where we don't care about waiting threads, only about whether the exclusive lock is held or not.

        Specified by:
        force in interface IndexProxy
        Overrides:
        force in class AbstractDelegatingIndexProxy
        Throws:
        IOException

      • barge

        private static void barge​(ReentrantReadWriteLock.ReadLock lock)
        Acquire the ReadLock in an unfair way, without waiting for queued up writers.

        The tryLock-method of the ReadLock implementation of ReentrantReadWriteLock implements a barging behaviour, where if an exclusive lock is not held, the shared lock will be acquired, even if there are other threads waiting for the lock. This behaviour is regardless of whether the lock is fair or not.

        This allows us to avoid deadlocks where readers would wait for writers that wait for readers in critical methods.

        The naive way to implement this method would be: 

        
     if ( !lock.tryLock() ) // try to barge
         lock.lock(); // fall back to normal blocking lock call
        This would however not implement the appropriate barging behaviour in a scenario like the following: Say the exclusive lock is held, and there is a queue waiting containing first a reader and then a writer, in this case the tryLock() method will return false. If the writer then finishes between the naive implementation exiting tryLock() and before entering lock() the barge(...) method would now block in the exact way we don't want it to block, with a read lock held and a writer waiting.
        In order to get around this situation, the implementation of this method uses a timed wait in a retry-loop in order to ensure that we make another attempt to barge the lock at a later point.

        This method is written to be compatible with the signature of Lock.lock(), which is not interruptible, but implemented based on the interruptible Lock.tryLock(long, TimeUnit), so the implementation needs to remember being interrupted, and reset the flag before exiting, so that later invocations of interruptible methods detect the interruption.

        Parameters:
        lock - a ReentrantReadWriteLock.ReadLock
